titleStmt.title: Description of University of Manchester Library, Gaster Hebrew MS 1380: Composite Yemenite manuscript

notesStmt.note: The first fragment on folios 1a-32b (or up to 33a?) runs from the end of Parashat Bo (בא; Exodus 10:1-13:16) until the end of the Pentateuch. However, the headings and the situation with the catchwords suggest that there is not just text missing at the beginning and end of the fragment, but also at several points within the fragment. Examples: the text on 1a-10b from Bo to Ki Tissa (Exodus 10:1-34:35) suddenly seems to jump to the end of Tazria' (Leviticus 12:1) on folio 11a; Parashat Shlah (Numbers 13:1-15:41) is missing between folios 24 and 25 and several parashiyyot in Numbers and Deuteronomy are missing between folios 28 and 29. The second fragment on folios 39a-40b discusses Parashat Shemot (שמות; Exodus 1:1-6:1). It seems that the two fragments belong to the same text, even though they are written in different hands, but this is not certain. The commentary contains various stories which Moses Gaster lists on the typescript that accompanies the manuscript.
Two types of paper: folios 1-38 and 39-40.
Loose leaf typescript abstracts of stories contained in the manuscript, produced by Moses Gaster in July 1923.
Qafih Joseph, Hamesh megillot ... 'im peirushim 'attiqim, Jerusalem: Ha-Agudah le-Hasalat Ginzei Teiman, 1962.
Langermann Tzvi Y., "Saving the Soul by Knowing the Soul: A Medieval Yemeni Interpretation of Song of Songs," Journal of Jewish Thought and Philosophy 12 (2003), 147-166.
Langermann Y. Tzvi, Yemenite Midrash: Philosophical Commentaries on the Torah, HarperCollins Publishers, 1996.
Langermann Y. Tzvi, "Sharh al-Dalala: A Commentary to Maimonides' Guide from Fourteenth Century Yemen," in Traditions of Maimonideanism, ed. Carlos Fraenkel (Leiden and Boston, 2009), pp. 155-176.

msContents.summary: Composite Yemenite manuscript containing (1) two incomplete Judeo-Arabic fragments from the same unknown philosophical commentary on the Torah or from two similar such commentaries (folios 1a-32b/33a and 39a-40b) and (2) an incomplete Judeo-Arabic commentary on Songs of Songs (folios 33a-38b). The Torah commentary contains many quotations in Hebrew. The commentary on Song of Songs is preceded by a rhymed Hebrew prologue. Although the name is not stated, the latter was written by Zechariah ben Solomon ha-Rofe, a prolific Yemenite author from the fifteenth century. Zechariah might also be the author of the Torah commentary. However, the present text is unlike the ones he is known to have written (for the genre and information about the author see Y. Tzvi Langermann, Yemenite Midrash: Philosophical Commentaries on the Torah, HarperCollins Publishers, 1996). The commentary on Song of Songs was published by Rabbi Yosef Qafih in Ḥamesh Megillot in Jerusalem in 1962 and studied by Y. Tzvi Langermann in "Saving the Soul by Knowing the Soul: A Medieval Yemeni Interpretation of Song of Songs," Journal of Jewish Thought and Philosophy 12 (2003), 147-166. In addition to the commentary on Song of Songs, a commentary on Maimonides' Guide of the Perplexed is announced but not found in the manuscript (folio 33a: עלי שיר השירים ואלדלאלה שרח). For a preliminary study relating to that as yet unpublished text see Y. Tzvi Langermann, "Sharh al-Dalala: A Commentary to Maimonides' Guide from Fourteenth Century Yemen," in Traditions of Maimonideanism, ed. Carlos Fraenkel (Leiden and Boston, 2009), pp. 155-176.

msItem.title: Gaster Hebrew MS 1380/1. Commentary on the Pentateuch (1a-33a, 39a-40b).
Gaster Hebrew MS 1380/2. Commentary on Song of Songs and the Guide for the Perplexed (33a-38b). Written by Zechariah ben Solomon ha-Rofe.

supportDesc.foliation: Modern pencil foliation in Arabic numerals at the top outer corner of side a of each folio.

layoutDesc.layout: Long line with 26 written lines; written area: 200 x 145 mm

decoDesc.decoNote: The initial words of this manuscript are made in red or black ink and delineated with red or black ink. There are also blank initial words with a colored outlining.
